frontmatter.title: Write mutation resolvers
frontmatter.description: Learn how a GraphQL mutation modifies data

children.value: We've written all of the resolvers we need for schema fields that apply to query operations. Now, let's write resolvers for our schema's
First, let's write a resolver for
, which enables a user to log in to our application. Add the following to your resolver map below the
address and returns corresponding user data from our
field to the object to represent the user's active session. In a later chapter, we'll learn how to persist this returned user data in our application client.

The authentication method used in our example application is not at all secure and should not be used by production applications. However, you can apply the principles demonstrated below to a token-based authentication method that
that clients can use to authenticate themselves to our server. Now, we need to add logic to our server to actually perform the authentication.
// simple auth check on every request
// find a user by their email

If the decoded value resembles an email address, obtain user details for that email address from the database and return an object that includes those details in the
object at the beginning of each operation's execution, all of our resolvers can access the details for the logged-in user and perform actions specifically

We're ready to test out our mutations! Restart your server and return to the Apollo Studio Explorer or GraphQL Playground in your browser.
GraphQL mutations are structured exactly like queries, except they use the
keyword. Paste the mutation below and run it:
The server will respond like this:
field is our login token (which is just the Base64 encoding of the email address we provided). We'll use this value in the next mutation.
Let's try booking some trips. Only authenticated users are allowed to book trips, so we'll include our login token in our request.
First, paste the mutation below into your tool's query editor:
Next, paste the following into the tool's Headers panel:
Run the mutation. You should see a success message, along with the
s of the trips we just booked.

Running mutations manually like this is a helpful way to test out our API, but a real-world application needs additional tooling to make sure its data graph grows and changes safely. In the next section, we'll connect our server to Apollo Studio to activate that tooling.
